dc:description:
The T-box 5 (TBX5) gene is located on chromosome 12 at 12q24.21 and encodes a transcriptional regulator that is involved in cardiac development and limb pattern formation Mutations in TBX5 were first reported in relation to autosomal dominant Holt-Oram syndrome (HOS), a developmental disorder affecting the heart and upper limb, in 1997 (Basson et al., 1997, PMID: 8988165; Li et al., 1997, PMID: 8988164). At least 120 unique variants (missense, nonsense, frameshift, small deletions) have been reported in humans, the majority which are de novo. The upper-limb malformations associated with HOS are fully penetrant, whereas the congenital heart malformations associated with the disease may be less so. In some cases, the cardiac phenotype may be recognized prior to limb anomalies, as some upper limb malformations have a very mild presentation. In patients with mild upper limb anomalies, conduction defects may present well into adulthood with reverse phenotyping prompting skeletal assessment (PMID 29755943). Cardiac conduction defects that are associated with HOS may occur in the presence or absence of structural heart defects. While septal defects are the most common structural disease association, cardiac phenotypes including dilated and non-compaction cardiomyopathies, and complex congenital heart diseases including dextrocardia, tetralogy of fallot, and double outlet right ventricle have been reported (PMIDs 3055242, 25344219, 32449309).

Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental data.The mechanism for TBX5 is haploinsufficiency (Basson et al., 1999, PMID:10077612; Gruenauer-Kloevekorn et al., 2003, PMID 12818525; Baban et al., 2014, PMID 24664498). This gene-disease association is supported by animal models, protein interaction studies. Functional alterations were also shown in non-patient cells harbouring missense variants in TBX5 in different affected individuals. In summary, TBX5 is definitively associated with Holt-Oram syndrome. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel on the meeting date 26Jan2021 (SOP Version 8). The summary was updated by the ClinGen Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease GCEP after meeting on March 25, 2025.
curationReasonDescription: >2 publications about gene-disease relationship since original publication in year 1997.

evidence.dc:description:
Direct binding of TBX5 transcriptional factor to DNA is required for activation of its target gene including NPPA encoding the Atrial natriuretic factor. To identify the mechanism by which TBX5 missense mutations cause Holt-Oram syndrome, the authors assessed the ability of mutant TBX5 proteins to bind to its target DNA-binding site using electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA). Three mutations in the T-domain, including G80R, R237Q, R237W, dramatically reduced the binding ability of TBX5 to DNA (Fig. 2A). The relative DNA-binding abilities of wild type and mutant G80R and R237Q TBX5 were determined using various concentrations of proteins. As shown in Fig. 2, C and D, both mutant proteins have much lower affinity to DNA than wild
type TBX5.

Mutations I54T and S252I had moderate effect on DNA binding of TBX5. In contrast, there was no significant difference in DNA binding between the wild type TBX5 and mutants Q49K and G169R (Fig. 2A)
evidence.rdfs:label: EMSA - DNA binding

evidence.dc:description:
Interacting gene(s): NKX2-5, NPPA

The cardiac homeobox protein Nkx2-5 is a vertebrate homolog of Drosophila tinman, which is required for its dorsal vessel development. Heterozygous mutations of the human homolog, C5X (encodes Nkx2-5), cause congenital heart diseases including atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect and tetralogy of Fallot.

COS-7 mammalian cells were transfected with constructs encoding FLAG-tagged Tbx5 and hemagglutinin (HA)-tagged Nkx2-5. Western blot analysis showed that Tbx5 was co-immunoprecipitated with Nkx2-5 (Fig. 1a,b). This was also exhibited in yeast two-hybrid study with Nkx2-5 as the 'bait' and sequence analysis showed one isolated cDNA encoded the N-terminal domain and T-box of Tbx5. The results indicate Tbx5 and Nkx2-5 specifically associate with each other. 

To elucidate the function of the association of Tbx5 and Nkx2-5 in cardiac development, their transcriptional activities were examined using the cardiac-specific Nppa promoter. Overexpression of Nkx2-5 activated the Nppa promoter as reported previously. Similarly, Tbx5 also transactivated Nppa (Fig. 2a), and simultaneous transfection of Tbx5 and Nkx2-5 substantially activated the promoter of Nppa transactivation (Fig. 2b). Neither coexpression
of T (brachyury) and Nkx2-5 nor of Hoxb6 and Tbx5 have a synergistic effect on expression of Nppa (Fig. 2b). These results indicate that Tbx5 and Nkx2-5 specifically associate and
produce a synergistic effect on the transcription of Nppa.
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-immunoprecipitation (TBX5, NKX2-5 and NPPA)

evidence.dc:description:
Similar cardiac septal defects are observed in the setting of human GATA4 mutations and human TBX5 mutations. TBX5 cooperates with GATA4 to activate transcription. Both wild-type proteins could immunoprecipitated with one another (Fig. 3b). Co-expression of TBX5 and Gata4 in HeLa cells and primary cardiomyocytes resulted in cooperative activation of the ANF reporter (Fig. 3c). 

Six unique TBX5 missense mutations (G80R, R237W, Q49K, I54T, G169R, S252I) from families that display HOS (Fig. 4a) were examined for their ability to interact with wild-type Gata4 or Nkx2-5. All TBX5 mutants co-immunoprecipitated with Gata4 or Nkx2-5 except for the G80R and R237W mutants (Fig. 4b). In contrast, G80R and R237W were able to interact with several other cardiac transcription factors (I.S.K. and D.S., unpublished data), suggesting specific disruption of TBX5–Gata4/Nkx2-5 complexes. The reciprocal evidence that human GATA4 and TBX5 mutations affect interaction with one another in the setting of similar CHDs provides support that GATA4 and TBX5 may cooperate during cardiogenesis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Coimmunoprecipitation (TBX5 and GATA4)

evidence.dc:description:
To elucidate the biological functions of Tbx5 and its mutants, the authors established P19CL6 cell lines (a a derivative of mouse embryonal carcinoma P19 cells that can efficiently differentiate into beating cardiomyocytes) that overexpress wildtype Tbx5 or the G80R or R237Q mutant (CL6-WT, CL6-G80R and CL6-R237Q, respectively)

CL6-WT cells 
- Differentiated into beating cardiomyocytes at day seven
- Differentiated CL6-WT cells contracted more vigorously than parent P19CL6 cells, and some clusters of cells were spontaneously detached from the culture dish and formed beating bodies. 
- CL6-WT cells expressed cardiac genes such as Nkx2-5, Gata4, Mef2c, Crap and Nppa and the genes encoding myosin light polypeptide 2 (Myl2) and ATPase, Ca2+ transporting, cardiac muscle, slow twitch 2 (Atp2a2) more abundantly than did parental CL6 cells (Fig. 4). Myl2 and Crap were abundantly expressed in CL6-WT cells.

CL6-R237Q cells
- CL6-R237Q cells started to beat at day 10
- Expression of cardiac genes was slightly reduced in CL6-R237Q cells compared to CL6 cells

CL6-G80R cells
- CL6-G80R cells never differentiated into beating cardiomyocytes
- Cardiac genes were barely detectable in CL6-G80R cells (Fig. 4). 

These results indicate that Tbx5 promotes cardiac differentiation and that the G80R mutation of Tbx5 markedly impairs cardiomyocyte differentiation.
evidence.rdfs:label: P19CL6 cells - cardiomyocyte differentiation

evidence.dc:description:
The authors assessed the functional effect of TBX5 mutations on transcriptional activation using a reporter gene (ANF-Luc, Fig. 3A) in which the ANF promoter (region from −270 to +1 bp) was fused to the luciferase gene. The ANF-Luc reporter gene was co-transfected with wild type or various mutant TBX5 expression constructs into COS-7 cells. 

Transcriptional activity was examined and expressed as relative luciferase units. As shown in Fig. 3B, expression of wild type TBX5 activated transcription of the ANF promoter. 
Three mutations, including G80R, R237Q, and R237W, reduced transcription activation by TBX5, consistent with our data that these three mutations reduced DNA binding of TBX5. 
In contrast, TBX5 mutations Q49K, I54T, G169R, and S252I had little effect on transcriptional activation by TBX5 (Fig. 3B). Western blot analysis showed that both wild type and all mutant TBX5 proteins were successfully expressed in transfected cells (Fig. 3C).
evidence.rdfs:label: COS-7 cells - Transcriptional activation of ANF

evidence.dc:description:
Heterozygous mice that are deficient in Tbx5 (Tbx5del/+ mice) showed heart and limb abnormalities that resembled patients with Holt-Oram syndrome. Tbx5del/+ mice had subtle defects of the paw and wrist, elongated phalangeal segments of first forelimb digit (equivalent to the human thumb) and hypoplastic falciformis bones in the wrist which were not present in wild-type (Figures 2A and 2B). 

Tbx5del/+ mice had enlarged heart (cardiomegaly) (Figure 2C), large atrial septal defects which were not seen in wild-type. (Figure 2E-2H). Adult Tbx5del/+ mice had heart conduction abnormalities - broad P-wave (indicative of atrial depolarization) consistent with the presence of atrial enlargement, prolonged P-Q intervals (first degree atrioventricular block) and frequent sinoatrial pauses (transient failure of atrial impulse generation) (Figure 3 and Table 1)
evidence.rdfs:label: Murine model (TBX5 and cardiac and upper limb phenotype)

evidence.dc:description:
The findings in the paper demonstrated a critical role for Tbx5 in the development of the specialized electrophysiologic system of the heart. Tbx5 is expressed in the central conduction system including the atrioventricular node, atrioventricular bundle and
ventricular bundle branches. In the atrioventricular canal, Tbx5 has specific roles in postnatal morphologic and functional maturation of the atrioventricular node and atrioventricular
bundle. In the ventricular conduction system, Tbx5 is required for morphologic maturation of the atrioventricular bundle and left bundle branch and is essential for the patterning and
function of the right bundle branch.

Various cardiac arrhythmias had been reported in patients with Holt-Oram syndrome, including various degrees of atrioventricular block, right bundle branch block, sinus arrest, sinus node dysfunction, atrial fibrillation/flutter. These can be explained by the findings in the model system phenotype.
evidence.rdfs:label: Murine model (TBX5 and cardiac conduction system)

member.rdfs:label: K5 III-1
member.detectionMethod: The forward and reverse strand of exons 1-9 of TBX5, including the flanking splice-recognition sequences, were analysed

evidence.dc:description: The number of TBX5 gene sequence analysis in the affected family members was not clearly stated in the manuscript.
evidence.rdfs:label: Family A

member.rdfs:label: Proband Family A
member.detectionMethod: All exons (exons 2-9) encoding the TBX5 polypeptide were amplified by the PCR and sequenced.
member.previousTestingDescription: Linkage analysis using highly polymorphic short tandem-repeat sequences dispersed throughout the genome. Gene responsible for Holt-Oram syndrome in Family A was detected to be on chromosome 12q2 (The maximal two-point LOD scores achieved with short tandem-repeat markers D12S79, DAO-2 and D12S84 were each greater than 6.0 (recombination fraction = 0.05). [Basson et al 1999]

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Thenar and carpal bone deformities, Mildly hypoplastic clavicles, thenar abnormalities included distal displacement of the thenar eminence in the presence or absence of a triphalangeal digit, aplastic thumb, atrial septal defects - ostium secundum type (mainly) and ostium primum, cardiac conduction defects - bradycardia, atrioventricular block, atrial fibrillation and sinus nosde dysfunction

member.rdfs:label: Proband for Family IId
member.detectionMethod: All exons (exons 2-9) encoding the TBX5 polypeptide were amplified by the PCR and sequenced.

member.rdfs:label: Proband for Family IIg
member.detectionMethod: All exons (exons 2-9) encoding the TBX5 polypeptide were amplified by the PCR and sequenced. The mutation was confirmed by amplication refractive mutation specific (ARMS) PCR using oligonucleotide primers CCATGTCATCACYGCCCT and 7GF.

member.rdfs:label: Proband for Family E
member.detectionMethod: All exons (exons 2-9) encoding the TBX5 polypeptide were amplified by the PCR and sequenced.

evidence.rdfs:label: HOS-B
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: short digit - small thumb, absent left middle finger, syndactyly - between right middle and ring fingers

member.rdfs:label: K1 II-2
member.detectionMethod: The forward and reverse strand of exons 1-9 of TBX5, including the flanking splice-recognition sequences, were analysed

member.rdfs:label: Proband for Family IIb
member.detectionMethod: All exons (exons 2-9) encoding the TBX5 polypeptide were amplified by the PCR and sequenced.

member.rdfs:label: HOS-A2
member.detectionMethod: PCR-SSCP Analysis and direct sequencing. PCR-primer pairs from intronic sequences flanking exons 2-8 of TBX5. Primers used to amplify the exonic sequences of HOS patients. Purified PCR products were subjected to direct sequencing using an ABI 377 automatic DNA sequencer

evidence.dc:description: Segregation analysis cannot be performed as the number of affected family members in family B who underwent molecular diagnosis was not stated clearly in the article
evidence.rdfs:label: Family B

member.rdfs:label: Proband in Family B
member.detectionMethod: To identify mutations in the coding sequence of TBX5, primers designed from intron sequences flanking exons 2-8 were used to amplify the genomic DNA from probands. The nucleotide sequence of each PCR-amplified exon was determined by cycle sequencing.
member.previousTestingDescription: Family B had genetic-linkage analysis performed with polymorphic DNA loci dispersed throughout the genome and linkage of the disease in the family to polymorphic loci on the long arm of chromosome 12 (combined multipoint lod score, 16.8). The data suggest odds greater than 10e16:1 that the genetic defect for Holt-Oram syndrome is present on the long arm of chromosome 12 (12q2). [Basson et al 1994]

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Severe ectromelia, digitalized thenar bones, deformed radius, conduction defect
